okay, you can always do `cal | grep "21"`. Can anyone tell me what's the output?
not working
the entire line is printed with 21 in red colour

<@UAGR7CFEJ> correct
now can you think of the cut command and do something?
the cut command selects some portion of the text and prints it out
ah yes it worked
hint: think of `cut -c n1,n2`
in the terminal itself or in a file?
terminal itself
Does anyone remember what the '-c' is for?
characters
okay, try this : `cal | grep "21" | cut -c 13,14`
prints 21
but when I used cal | grep 21 | cut -c 21,22 it gave a different result
correct, that's because the characters at positions 21 and 22 are different
so, you can see that this is not extendable to different months, because the position of "21" will be different
any other ideas?
The characters in those positions are just spaces
how do you delimit using the cut command?
the cal has spaces in between numbers right, this could be a start
can we print characters,bytes etc of a given range?
`cut -d' '`
thats a good idea
what would the command be
so, this command splits the input based on ' ' and separates them into fields
the remaining job is to choose the appropriate field
so shall I proceed?
`cal | grep "21" | cut -d' ' -f 5` : this prints out 21. Can anyone explain why?
21 is the fifth number in the output
more generally, it's the fifth field
yeah my bad
this is still not the best answer, because we need to know the field of the number in every month
what does `grep -o something.txt` do?
`cut -c a-b` ?
cut -c n1-n2
Anyone?:sweat_smile:
okay the `-o` options prints an O/P iff there exists an exact match
so, `cal | grep -o "21"` will print out only 21
any doubts so far?
something like a search function?
I don't understand what you mean by search
grep will print the complete line which matches the pattern
but -o option will only print the appropriate part, that's the difference
<@UAH8CT90X> has joined the channel
okay we will start with the first shell script
ohh
create a file with ".sh" extension in a directory
the extension only helps us find the shell scripts quickly, the OS doesn't differentiate files based on their extensions
What is the need for shell scripting? Basically if you combine many commands and want to execute many of them one after the other, you would store it in a file and execute them
This ".sh" file is called a script. Since you have shell commands, it's called shell script.
So instead of entering each command on the terminal, you can have it all in a file.
Understood?
okay, at the beginning of the script, you need to tell the OS what interpreter to use
we can write scripts using python, perl. bash, etc.
that's why we use a shebang - `#!/bin/bash`
Any doubts?
the shebang line indicates that we are using the bash interpreter, which can be found at the folder /bin/
it could also be `#!/usr/bin/perl`, `#!/usr/bin/python`, etc for different scripts
but if it is not specified, it will assume bash to be the default interpreter
is everyone with me?
Anyone knows what 'bash' stands for?
bourne again shell
okay, inside the file enter: `echo "This is my first shell script"`
okay, to make a file, there are many ways
`touch filename`, will create a file name, but does not open it
more easily, `subl filename`, `vi filename` will create and open the file
'subl' is for an editor called Sublime text that you need to explicitly download. But guys it's worth it. Do download it after the session
does it replace vim?
it's an alternative
it doesn't replace it, its another editor
oh so you can use both ?
but many find vi to be the most productive  editor
yeah, you can always use both. it's used for writing programs
i want sublime but idk if it will work for wsl
I like sublime better:yum:
<@UAH07G9T9> can enlighten us on the greatness of vim, I would love to have a session
okay, you guys entered an echo statement inside the scrpt?
If you have any doubts please feel free to ask us
okay, now the file can be run as `bash filename`
but, the file does not have the execute permission, so we can't run it as `./filename`
every file has an attribute called permissions
the `ls -l` lists out the permissions in the first column
the "rwx" denotes the permissions
so there user, group and others
We can change the permissions using the "chmod" command
we can use chmod to change file permissions
so, to be able to execute a file, it needs to have execute permission for the current user
`chmod +x filename` will give the execute access
any doubts?
now, you can execute the script as ./filename also
previously, you would have got a `permission denied` message
okay, moving on, let's look at the basics of if-else constructs
you can look at the syntax here - <https://www.tutorialspoint.com/unix/if-elif-statement.htm>

attachments.text: Unix / Linux Shell The if...elif...fi statement - Learning fundamentals of UNIX in simple and easy steps : A beginner's tutorial containing complete knowledge of Getting Started, Unix Korn and Bourne Shell and Programming, File Permission / Access Modes, Environment, Utilities, Pipes and Filters, Network Communication Utilities, File System, Directories, Memory Management, Special Variables, vi editor, What is Shell?, Using Shell Variables, Arrays, Basic Operators, Decision Making, Loop Types, Control, Substitution, Quoting Mechanisms, Input / Output Redirections, Functions, Man Page Help, Regular Expressions with SED, User Administration, System Performance, Logging, Signals and Traps, Processes.
attachments.fallback: www.tutorialspoint.com: Unix / Linux Shell The if...elif...fi statement

text: basically, the condition to be evaluated is placed within the square braces
the reason is, the if stmt, by itself cannot evaluate relational and logical expressions
so, we can use another stmt called `test` to evaluate the conditional statements
the programs look a little like C#
or, equivalently use `[]`
importantly, the spaces inside the `[]` are very important, and must be preserved as is
yeah it does, but the spacing is crucial for it to work
so `if [expression 1]` is invalid?
how will the syntax be for this case?
okay, how do you know how many arguments have been passed to the script?
'test' works for comparing two numbers, two strings and file attributes.
test val1 operator val2

if test $1 -gt 0
then
echo "$1 number is positive"
I want you to try it out and tell me:joy:
so, shell scripting has something called special variables, which come in very handy, while writing shell scripts - <https://www.tutorialspoint.com/unix/unix-special-variables.htm>

text: instead of the relational operators ==,<=,>=,>,<,!= that u use in C, shell uses -eq(equal),-le(less than or eq),-ge,-gt,lt,-ne etc
is test a command?
or just a keyword
so, the number of args passed to our script can be accessed via the variable `$#`
similarly, the first arg is placed in $1, second arg is contained in $2, etc
everyone clear?
<@UAFHUCYAG> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAFHUCYAG/FB0UR003Y/-.sh|Untitled>

file.name: -.sh
file.title: Untitled
file.preview:
if [ $1 -eq $2 ] then
	echo "The args are equal"
else
	echo "the args are not equal"
fi
file.preview_highlight:
if [ $1 -eq $2 ] then
	echo "The args are equal"
else
	echo "the args are not equal"
fi

text: the if construct always ends with `fi`
`-eq` checks if the two args are equal
fi is like the '}' that you learnt in C
it showed `./sample.sh: line 3: [10==15]: command not found`
<@UAFHUCYAG> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAFHUCYAG/FAZRBRXRS/elif_construct.sh|elif construct>

file.name: elif_construct.sh
file.title: elif construct
file.preview:
if [ expression 1 ]
then
   Statement(s) to be executed if expression 1 is true
elif [ expression 2 ]
then
file.preview_highlight:
if [ expression 1 ]
then
   Statement(s) to be executed if expression 1 is true
elif [ expression 2 ]
then
